Question_1.Context: The study investigated the anti-H. pylori activity of rutin and rutin nanocrystals (RNCs).
Question_1.Question: What was the inhibition zone (IZ) of RNCs against Helicobacter pylori compared to rutin and the standard control?
Question_1.Source: RNCs exhibited anti-H. pylori activity with a significantly (p < 0.05) inhibition zone of 22.67 mm while rutin exhibited less inhibition zone of 18 mm and the standard control had an inhibition zone of 19.5 mm.

Question_2.Context: The study evaluated the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) and minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC) of rutin and RNCs against H. pylori.
Question_2.Question: What was the MIC of RNCs against Helicobacter pylori?
Question_2.Source: MIC and MBC of RNCs (7.8 µg/mL) were less than MIC and MBC of rutin (62.5 µg/mL).

Question_3.Context: The study assessed the anti-biofilm activity of rutin and RNCs against Helicobacter pylori.
Question_3.Question: What was the biofilm inhibition percentage of RNCs at 75% of the minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC)?
Question_3.Source: Biofilm formation of H. pylori was more affected by RNCs compared to rutin at all used doses of MBC, where at 75% of MBC, the anti-biofilm percentage was 92.12% using RNCs.

Question_4.Context: The study investigated the urease inhibition activity of rutin and RNCs against Helicobacter pylori.
Question_4.Question: What was the IC50 value of rutin for urease inhibition?
Question_4.Source: Promising IC50 (6.85 µg/mL) was recorded for urease inhibition using RNCs while rutin exhibited an IC50 value of 97.8 µg/mL.

Question_5.Context: The study examined the cytotoxicity of rutin and RNCs against HT-29 cells.
Question_5.Question: What was the IC50 value of rutin against HT-29 cells?
Question_5.Source: The IC50 value of rutin against HT-29 cells was 184.96 ± 4.33 µg/mL.

Question_6.Context: The study investigated the hemolysis inhibition activity of rutin and RNCs.
Question_6.Question: What was the hemolysis inhibition percentage of RNCs at 800 µg/mL?
Question_6.Source: Different percentages (72.2, 77.3, 81.9, 87.8, 93.9, and 99.9%) of hemolysis inhibition were recorded using RNCs at various concentrations, including 800 µg/mL.

Question_7.Context: The study assessed the butyrylcholinesterase inhibition activity of rutin and RNCs.
Question_7.Question: What was the IC50 value of RNCs for butyrylcholinesterase inhibition?
Question_7.Source: RNCs exhibited a lower IC50 value of 12.74 µg/mL for butyrylcholinesterase inhibition compared to the IC50 of rutin, which was 18.15 µg/mL.

Question_8.Context: The study conducted molecular docking experiments of rutin with specific proteins.
Question_8.Question: What was the binding score of rutin with the crystal structure of H. pylori (PDB code: 4HI0)?
Question_8.Source: Rutin has predicted strong binding interactions against the examined protein 4HI0 with a low binding score of -7.47778 kcal/mol.

Question_9.Context: The study performed molecular docking experiments of rutin with specific proteins.
Question_9.Question: What was the binding score of rutin with the crystal structure of colon cancer (PDB code: 2HQ6)?
Question_9.Source: Rutin exhibited a binding score of -7.68511 kcal/mol with the crystal structure of colon cancer (PDB code: 2HQ6).

Question_10.Context: The study conducted molecular docking experiments of rutin with specific proteins.
Question_10.Question: What was the binding score of rutin with the crystal structure of butyrylcholinesterase (PDB code: 6EMI)?
Question_10.Source: Rutin exhibited a low binding score of -9.50333 kcal/mol with the crystal structure of butyrylcholinesterase (PDB code: 6EMI).
